title: Topic marking particle 은/는
details: Topic marking particle 은/는. 'As for me...'
examples:
저는 학생이에요
As for me, I'm a student

내가 제일 잘 나가
I am the best

title: Subject marking particle 이/가
details: Subject marking particle 이/가. The subject of the sentence. Usually the one performing an action on the object.
examples:
내가 제일 잘 나가
I am the best

title: Object marking particle 을/를
details: Object marking particle 을/를. That to which the action happens
examples:
저는 학생이에요
As for me, I'm a student

사과를 먹어요
I'm eating an apple

title: Let's -아/-어/-여 | -(으)시죠 | -자 | -(으)ㄹ래요 | -(으)실래요
details:
"Let's" (do something)
-아/-어/-여 [polite/pain] -> exact same as normal conjugation
-(으)시죠 [honorific]
-자 [informal]
-(으)ㄹ래요 [polite/casual]
-(으)실래요 [polite/formal]
examples:
시작해요
시작하시죠 [honorific]
시작하자 [informal]
시작할래요 [polite/casual]
시작하실래요 [polite/formal]

title: -게
details: A connective ending used when the preceding statement is the purpose, result, method, amount, etc., of something mentioned in the following statement.

title: -(으)ㄴ 다음에 / 후에 / 뒤에 (After...some verb)
details:
Turns a verb into a adjective and indicates that what follows will occur after the action that is being conjugated.
다음 = next
후 = after
뒤 = behind/back
에 means "at" so combined they mean "at" the location in time "after" what is being described
All 3 can be used interchangeably in this form

Just like with other verbs turned into an adjective, the tense of the first verb is determined by the tens of the second verb (because only the second is conjugated)
examples:
집에 간 후에 책을 읽었어요
After I went home, I read a book.

title: 그래도 / -아/어/여도
details:
그래 = 그렇게 헤 or 그렇게 하여
    = To do in such a way, to do that. Used by itself to agree with something.
-도 = also, even, too
So, 그래도 means nevertheless, even if, however, but still.
It is a sentence starter.

-아/어/여도 after a verb has the  exact same meaning. Just like with -고, the verb followed by -도 does not have a tense but instead inherits its tense from the verb conjugated in the part of the sentence that follows.
examples:
비가 와요. 그래도 갈 거예요?
It's raining. Are you still going (despite that)?

비가 와도 갈 거예요?
Even though it's raining, are you still going?
Are you going, even though it's raining?

바빠도 한 한국에 갈 거예요
Even if I'm busy, I will go to Korea.

title: -의 (of)
details:
The english word "of" in the posessive sense. If the phrase cannot be rewriten using 's, it is not possessive and so not 의.

Used as suffix to word that is is a description of, followed by the description.

Sometimes pronouced as 에
examples:
내 친구의 이름
My friend's name
The name of my friend

NOT this type of "of" (just use the counter instead)
One of my friends
제 친구 한 명
A piece if cake
케니크 한 조각

title: A glass/cup of. A drink
details: Counter for a drink, specifying a cup/glass or similar
examples:
우유 한잔
A glass of milk
커피 한잔
A cup of coffee
물 한잔
A glass of water

title: 거 / 것 (thing)
details:
Thing. While 것 is the correct spelling, 거 is very common both spoken and written because it's more smooth to say.

Often combined with other parts of grammar as a sort of glue and very loosely means "thing"
examples:
이거 / 저거 / 그거
This thing / that thing / the thing (that was mentioned. Normally "that" in English)

갈 거예요
I will be going / Going is the "thing" I will be in the future

산 거 봐요
Look at what I bought / "The buying", look at it. The verb becomes a noun, a thing

title: -는 것 (Verbs into nouns)
details:
Turn a verb into a noun to make it part of the middle of the sentence. A sentence can only end in a real verb (or connected with -고 -서 etc).

-은/ㄴ = past tense
-는 = present tense
-을/ㄹ = future tense
examples:
산 것 봐요
Look at what I bought
사는 거 봐요
Look at what I'm buying
살 거 봐요
Look at what I will buy

title: -(으)ㄹ까 (I wonder / Shall we?)
details: Turns the whole sentence into a question, wondering if something is a certain way or if someone wants to do something.
examples:
먹을까요
Shall we eat? Do you want to eat?
언제 사랑이 올까
When will love come? / I wonder when love will come

title: -는/은/ㄴ데 (linking verbs)
details:
1) 는데 after action verbs
2) 은데 after descriptive verbs with final consonant in verb stem
3) ㄴ데 after descriptive verbs with final vowel
Ends in ㄹ or ㅎ) Drop the ㄹ/ㅎ
Ends in ㅂ) drop the ㅂ and add 우, then the normal rules

Note that all of these use 는데, even if they end in a vowel:
이다, 아니다, 있다, 없다, -았 or -겠

Above is present tense.
Past tense: take verbstem and add 는데
Eg. 했다 (To do) -> 했는데
Future tense: same
할거다 (to do) -> 할건데

--------
Usage
--------
1) First half of the sentence (ending in 데) explains or puts the second part into context or contrasts the 2 parts.
It means and/or and is similar to a semi-colon. It is used to contrast 2 sentences and sounds softer than 고 or 지만

2) Showing surprise or exclamation

3) Asking a question, expecting an explanation

4) Suggesting that you expect an answer or reponse (similar to trailing off in English with so...)
examples:
하다 하는데
먹다 먹는데 (Mongneunde)
작다 작은데 (Small)
예쁘다 예쁜데
멀다 먼데 (Far)

살다 (To live) -> 사는데
맵다 (To be spicy) -> 매운데

title: Descriptive verb + -ㄴ/은 (adjectives)
details:
Adjectives and verbs both have the same dictionary form, ending in -다
Eg. 가다 (to go) and 바쁘다 (to be busy)
Verbs are actually split into:
+ Action verbs ("normal" verbs)
+ Descriptive verbs (adjectives)

Adjectives can be used as a verb, by congugating the stem with 아/어/여 or as actual adjectives by adding ㄴ/은
Eg 저는 바빠요 (I am busy) or 바쁜 사람 (a busy person)

Note that -이에요 is used for verbs, not adjectives. I am busy is NOT 저는 바쁜이에요.

title: Action verb + -는 (adjective)
details:
See the explanation for descriptive verb adjectives.

Action verbs become adjectives by adding -는 to the verb stem.
**If the verb stem ends in ㄹ, the ㄹ is dropped**
Eg. 열다 -> 여는 (to open)
examples:
노래하는 사람
Singing person

좋아하는 사람
liked person (a person that I like)
NOT "person that likes" -> It describes the person, not what the person does.

title: Can / cannot | might/maybe/perhaps
source: TTMIK Level 2 Lesson 17 p103 & Level 3 Lesson 22 p141
details:
Can do something
-(으)ㄹ 수 있다
Cannot do something
-(으)ㄹ 수 없다

Using ㄹ indicates future tense.
수 = Way/method/idea
So there will be a way, therefor it CAN be (but isn't yet, so future)

Maybe/might/perhaps
-(으)ㄹ 수도 있다
There will also be a way/one of the ways -> one of these ways might happen

NOTE that for negative, the modifier is added before 수도 but 있다 does NOT become 없다
examples:
읽을 수 있어(I can read)
잘 수 없어서 (couldn't sleep)
한국어 할 있어요 (I can speak Korean)

저 내일 올 수도 있어요
I might come here tomorrow

저 내일 안 올 수도 있어요
I might not come here tomorrow

저 내일 못 올 수도 있어요
I might not be able to come here tomorrow

title: To be good/bad/unable
details:
To be good at: 잘 (good)
To be unable to: 못 (not)
To be bad at: 잘 못 (good not)
To do in the wrong way: 잘못
To make a mistake: 잘못하다

There are 2 ways to use these:
1) With 하다 verbs, the noun of the verb becomes the object (을/를) and 잘/못/etc is placed in between:
Eg. 공부를 못해요 (I cannot study)
2) With all other verbs, 잘/못/etc is simply placed in front of the verb with a space
Eg. 잘 도왖줘 (I'm good at helping)

IMPORTANT
Spaces (pauses) make a difference:
1) Good/bad with 하다: always without space (잘하다 / 못하다) (ja-ra-da / mo-ta-da)
2) Good/bad with other verbs: always with space (잘하 ...다 / 못 ...다) (jal verb / mot verb)
3) Space between 잘 and 못 and verb: to be bad at
공불 잘 못 해 (I'm bad at studying)
4) To do the wrong way: 잘못 해 (jal-mot hae)
5) To make a mistake. 잘못해 (jal-mo-tae)

title: 이다 (to be)
details:
Verb used as particle for nouns.
Becomes -이에요 or -예요 depending on whether the noun ends in a vowel or consonant.

The verb stem is 이 which means that when conjugated to become a noun itself, it becomes -인.
Eg. It's my birthday
오늘 생일이에 (Normal)
오늘 생일인대! (Exclamation)

title: Plural -들
details: -들 is used for plural of a noun
examples:
친구들
Friends
학샹들
Students

title: -네요 (impressed/surprised)
details:
Verb stem + -네요
Expresses being impressed, surprised or a personal thought
examples:
크다 - To be big
커요
크네요

맞다 To be correct
맞아 (Maja)
맛네 (Mannae)

title: -만
details:
1.only; alone; just; merely; as many as; as far as.
2.at least.

Suffix for nouns but also verbs that are turned into nouns
examples:
너에게만
Only to you

보이지만

조금만
Only a little

보는 것만
Only what can be seen

title: 아/어/여서 (therefore/so)
details: Links sentences together.
examples:
비가 와서 못 가요
It's raining so I can't go
비가 와서 못 갔어요
It rained, so I couldn't go

title: Honerific suffix -시다
details:
Added to make the sentence more polite.
-시다
-셔요 -> -세요
https://www.howtostudykorean.com/unit-2-lower-intermediate-korean-grammar/unit-2-lessons-34-41/lesson-39/
examples:
안녕하세요
왜 예쁜 날 두고 가시나

title: Question to oneself suffix -나
details:
Suffix used when asking a question that is more directed to oneself
Not quite the same as -카 which is to wonder about something.
examples: 왜 예쁜 날 두고 가시나

title: Leave behind 두고 가
details:
두다 is to put or place
가다 Is to go
두고 가 is to leave behind
examples: 왜 예쁜 날 두고 가시나

title: -지 /죠 (question confirmation)
details:
..eh?
...right?
...isn't it?
examples:
맛있지 / 맛있죠 ?
It's delicious, right?

title: 군(요) realising (didn't know that)
details:
If used with action verb:
-는군요
Eg. 공부하는군요
Oh, I didn't realise you were studying

-구나 -> a little more emphasis and only casual
examples:
맛있군요
Oh, that's actually delicious

Most common:
그렇군요 -> 그렇다 to be a certain way
Oh, I didn't know that (it was that way)

title: -거든(요) FYI, just so you know, hey....
details:
Informing, you think they don't know.
Intonation:
* Rising: on 든 or 요 but not all of 든요. Mocking or condescending (rude) Very common among friends
* Falling: neutral and more safe. When you genuinely want to inform them of something.

Cannot be used in a question

title: -잖아(요) expressing that you are right
details:
It's something the other person already knows.
Never polite, even with 요
Comes from -지 않아요

있잔라 Is used at the beginning of a sentence to get their attention. Like "hey" in English
examples:
좋아하잖아 or past tense 좋아했잔하
Hey, you know it's (was) good!

알지 않아요 / 앙잔하요
Hey, you know!

title: -고 "and" or make sound softer
details:
1) used to connect sentences with "and"
2) used to make a sentence sound softer. It's not followed by another sentence. Most commonly:
아니고(요) Which is saying no without making it a statement. When you are not trying to sound super certain. DO NOT OVERUSE

title: -나 (doesn't matter what option is chosen)
examples:
눈이 오나 비가 오나 그는 닐을 한다
No matter if it snows or rains, he works

title: -지만 (but)
details:
먼 means only and 지 turns negative
So 지만 means not just this, but...

title: -서 (and)
details:
Use with conjugated form
ONLY PRESENT TENSE
해서
먹어서
가서
Exception: 이다 ->
After consonant: -이라서 instead of -이에요
After vowel: -라서 instead of -예요

Requirement
1) 2 action verbs are strongly related (while 고 can be for any 2 sentences)
2) second verb happens right after the first (action verbs)
3) cause -> effect (action or descriptive verbs)

title: -니까 (because)
details:
하다 -> 하니까
먹다 -> 먹으니까 (으 for consonants)
Exception: verb stems ending in ㄹ ㅎ or ㅂ -> remove first and for ㅂ, add 우.
Eg 덥다 -> 더우니까
Works with commands.
This is informal

CANNOT be used with an emotion (because happy/sad/sorry). Then use -서 instead
examples:
비가 오니까 우산을 가져가세요
Take an umbrella because it is raining (command).

비가 오니까 우산을 가져갔어요
Because it is raining, I brought zn umbrella.
Note that with this example, both -서 (cause/effect) and -니까 (because) work
